DOC.HEADLINE: COX NEWSPAPERS BUDGET FOR TUESDAY, AUG. 17

TEXT.P: Questions should be directed to Alan Gordon at 404-536-6751 or e-mail coxnews@nytimes.com.

POLICE-SHOOTING-GA -- ATLANTA -- Four years after rogue narcotics officers killed a 92-year-old woman while illegally raiding her home, the city of Atlanta has finally settled with her family. Mayor Kasim Reed announced Monday that the estate of Kathryn Johnston, led by her niece Sarah Dozier, would be getting a $4.9 million settlement. (Suggs, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

DEFLATION -- ATLANTA -- A specter is haunting your investment -- the specter of deflation. Only a fleeting fear six years ago, worry of an economy-wide slide in prices has returned, slipping into economists' discussions and shading investment decisions. There is no consensus -- just pressure to make the right call at a time when the stakes are high and the rules have changed. (Kanell, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

DELTA-UNIONS -- ATLANTA -- As Delta Air Lines workers prepare to vote in massive union representation elections later this year, labor leaders say wins at the company could influence organizing around the South. "Delta is an icon in Atlanta," said Patrick Scott, who works with the AFL-CIO-organized ATL Solidarity Committee, a coalition to support union efforts. The Delta elections will "set the tone" for other unionization campaigns, he said. (Yamanouchi, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)
TECHNOBUDDY -- ATLANTA -- Bring down the high price of printing. (Husted, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)
TECH-HELPDESK -- ATLANTA -- Q&A on technology issues. (Husted, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)
LUNCH-BREAK -- AUSTIN, Texas -- Refueling my mind and my belly by taking back my lunch hour. (Broyles, Austin American-Statesman)

DUVALL-GET-LOW -- AUSTIN, Texas -- To land the actor he wanted to play a shadowy old hermit in "Get Low," director Aaron Schneider had to work up his nerve and head out to the country to meet a real-life character, Robert Duvall. (Eaton, Austin American-Statesman)
EYMAN-ON-BOOKS -- WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Weekly books column. (Eyman, Palm Beach Post)

OUTDOORS-LEGGETT -- AUSTIN, Texas -- When I was a kid in East Texas, dove hunting was an afterthought, just a bridge that got us over September and into October when we could hunt squirrels. There were never many doves just enough to kill a few in an afternoon. Today doves are hunted all over Texas. There are plenty of them. It doesn't cost much. And, compared to other forms of hunting, it is accessible to young, old and, often, the disabled. (Leggett, Austin American-Statesman)
